definitions: examine something methodically and in detail to understand its nature or determine its essential features
treat a patient using psychoanalytic methods to understand unconscious motivations and resolve psychological problems
examples: Scientists analyse the data from multiple experiments carefully
We need to analyse the market trends before launching the product
The therapist will analyse your dreams during the session
Freud would analyse his patients for years at a time

definitions: examine something methodically and in detail to understand its nature or determine its essential features
treat a patient using psychoanalytic methods to understand unconscious motivations and resolve psychological problems
separate something into its constituent elements or component parts for detailed examination
examples: Scientists analyze the data from multiple experiments carefully
We need to analyze the market trends before launching the product
The therapist will analyze your dreams during the session
Freud would analyze his patients for years at a time
The laboratory will analyze the blood sample for diseases
Chemists analyze compounds to determine their molecular structure

definitions: secure a ship or boat in position using a heavy metal device dropped to the seabed
fix or secure something firmly in a particular place or position to prevent movement
present and coordinate a television or radio program as the main broadcaster
examples: The captain decided to anchor the yacht in the sheltered bay
We'll anchor here overnight before continuing the journey tomorrow
You need to anchor the shelf firmly to the wall
The climbing rope was anchored to a strong tree trunk
She anchors the evening news every weeknight at six
He has anchored the morning show for ten years

definitions: make someone feel strong displeasure or hostility by doing something offensive or provocative
examples: His rude comments really angered everyone at the meeting
It angers me when people arrive late without apologizing

definitions: move or position something so that it is not straight or perpendicular but at an angle
fish with a rod and line rather than nets or other commercial equipment
try to obtain something indirectly by hints or scheming rather than direct request
examples: She angled the mirror to catch the morning sunlight
The photographer angled his camera for a better shot
My grandfather loves to angle for trout in mountain streams
We spent the afternoon angling from the old wooden pier
He's obviously angling for a promotion with all that overtime
She was angling for an invitation to the exclusive party

definitions: experience or display severe mental suffering or emotional pain about something distressing
cause someone to experience severe mental or emotional pain through actions or circumstances
examples: She anguished over the difficult decision for several weeks
Parents anguish when their children are seriously ill
The news of the accident anguished the entire family
It anguished him to see his hometown destroyed

definitions: give life or energy to something making it active or appearing alive
create moving images by photographing successive positions of models or drawings for film or video
make someone or something lively or spirited by inspiring enthusiasm or excitement
examples: The puppet seemed to animate with its own mysterious life
Scientists hope to animate the preserved tissue using electricity
Disney animators animate thousands of drawings for each movie
She learned to animate characters using computer software
His passionate speech animated the crowd into enthusiastic action
Music always animates her when she's feeling depressed

definitions: incorporate territory into an existing political unit such as a country or state often by force
add or attach something as an extra or subordinate part especially to a document
examples: The empire annexed several neighboring territories during the war
Russia annexed Crimea despite international protests in twenty fourteen
Please annex the supporting documents to your main application
The lawyer annexed several exhibits to the legal brief

definitions: destroy something completely so that nothing remains or it ceases to exist entirely
defeat an opponent so thoroughly and decisively that they are unable to continue competing
examples: The asteroid impact would annihilate all life on the planet
Nuclear weapons could annihilate entire cities within seconds
Our team completely annihilated the opposition with a fifty-point victory
The chess master annihilated every challenger in the tournament

definitions: make a public and formal declaration about a fact or plan to inform people officially
make known the arrival or presence of someone formally especially at an event
examples: The company will announce its quarterly earnings tomorrow morning
The president announced new policies during the press conference
The butler announced each guest as they entered the ballroom
A trumpet fanfare announced the arrival of the king

definitions: make someone slightly angry or impatient by causing minor inconvenience or displeasure
harass or pester someone repeatedly with unwanted attention or persistent actions
examples: The constant noise from construction really annoys the neighbors
It annoys me when people talk during movies
The bully would annoy younger students every day after school
Telemarketers annoy people by calling during dinner time

definitions: declare something legally invalid or void especially a marriage or official decision retroactively
examples: The court decided to annul their marriage after discovering fraud
Parliament voted to annul the controversial law passed last year

definitions: give a spoken or written response to a question or request for information
respond to a telephone call or door by picking up or opening it
be responsible or accountable for one's actions especially to an authority
examples: She answered all the interview questions confidently and clearly
Please answer the email by tomorrow morning at latest
Can someone answer the phone while I'm in the meeting?
Nobody answered when I knocked on the front door
You'll have to answer for your mistakes to the board
The minister must answer to parliament for this decision

definitions: cause someone to become hostile or angry by opposing or irritating them deliberately or thoughtlessly
examples: His arrogant behavior tends to antagonize his coworkers unnecessarily
Try not to antagonize the neighbors with loud music

definitions: put up a stake or wager before receiving cards in poker or similar gambling games
pay an amount of money as one's share or contribution to a fund or venture
examples: Each player must ante five dollars before receiving their cards
You need to ante up if you want to play
Everyone needs to ante their share for the vacation rental
The investors all anted substantial sums for the startup

definitions: perform playful funny or absurd acts or movements to entertain or get attention
examples: The clowns would antic around the circus ring making children laugh
The comedian antics through his entire performance on stage

definitions: expect or predict that something will happen based on knowledge or experience
act before something happens by taking action to prepare for or prevent it
look forward to something pleasant with eager expectation and excitement
examples: Economists anticipate interest rates will rise next quarter significantly
We didn't anticipate such a large crowd at the event
Good chess players anticipate their opponent's moves several turns ahead
The company anticipated demand by increasing production last month
Children eagerly anticipate Christmas morning all through December
I anticipate seeing you at the reunion next month

definitions: search for and purchase old valuable objects in shops or markets specializing in antiques
treat or finish something to make it look old or like an authentic antique
examples: We love to antique in small towns during weekend trips
She spends her Saturdays antiquing at local estate sales
The furniture maker antiques new pieces using special staining techniques
They antiqued the mirror frame to match the vintage decor

definitions: imitate someone's behavior or manner especially in an absurd or unthinking way
examples: Children often ape their parents' mannerisms without realizing it
The comedian expertly aped the politician's distinctive speaking style

definitions: express regret for something wrong or inappropriate one has done to acknowledge fault
examples: She apologised sincerely for arriving late to the important meeting
The company apologised publicly for the data breach incident

definitions: express regret for something wrong or inappropriate one has done to acknowledge fault
examples: He apologized profusely for forgetting their anniversary dinner reservation
The airline apologized to passengers for the lengthy delay

definitions: dress or clothe someone in particular garments especially formal or special clothing
examples: The bride was beautifully appareled in white silk and lace
Knights were appareled in armor before going into battle

definitions: make a serious or urgent request for help or support especially to emotions or sense of justice
apply to a higher court for reversal of a lower court's decision
be attractive or interesting to someone by meeting their tastes or preferences
examples: The charity appeals for donations every December to help families
She appealed to his sense of fairness in the dispute
The defendant will appeal the guilty verdict to the supreme court
They appealed the decision but lost the case
This vacation package should appeal to families with young children
Classical music doesn't appeal to everyone's taste

definitions: come into sight or become visible especially suddenly or gradually from being hidden
give the impression of being or having a particular quality though not necessarily so
present oneself formally in a particular place especially in court or on stage
examples: A rainbow appeared in the sky after the storm
Cracks began to appear in the old wall
She appears tired after working such long hours
The situation appears to be improving slowly
The defendant must appear in court next Monday morning
The actor will appear in three performances this weekend

definitions: pacify or placate someone by acceding to their demands even if unreasonable
satisfy or relieve a feeling or need especially hunger or desire
examples: The government tried to appease protesters with minor policy changes
You can't appease bullies by giving them what they want
A small snack will appease your hunger until dinner
Nothing could appease his desire for revenge

definitions: add something to the end of a written document or other item as supplementary material
examples: Please append your signature to the bottom of the contract
The researcher appended extensive notes to her published paper

definitions: show approval or praise by clapping hands together repeatedly especially after a performance
express strong approval or admiration for an action or achievement
examples: The audience applauded enthusiastically for ten minutes after the concert
Everyone applauded when she received her diploma
Critics applaud the government's decision to increase education funding
We should applaud their efforts to reduce carbon emissions

definitions: put something into operation or practical use to achieve a particular purpose
make a formal request for something such as a job or admission typically in writing
spread or put a substance onto a surface using physical pressure or movement
be relevant or appropriate to a particular person or situation
examples: Scientists apply new theories to solve complex environmental problems
You should apply these principles in your daily work
She decided to apply for three different graduate programs
Over two hundred people applied for the position
Apply the cream gently to the affected area twice daily
The painter applied several coats to achieve the color
These regulations apply to all employees without any exception
The same rules apply whether you're at home or work

definitions: officially assign someone to a job or position of responsibility or authority
arrange or decide on a time or place for something to happen
examples: The board appointed her as the new chief executive officer
The president appoints federal judges to lifetime positions
We appointed three o'clock as our meeting time
They appointed the hotel lobby as their meeting place

definitions: feel or show gratitude for something someone has done or given
understand the full worth or significance of something through awareness or sensitivity
rise in value or price over time especially of property or investments
examples: I really appreciate your help with moving this weekend
She appreciates all the support from her family
You need experience to fully appreciate classical music's complexity
I didn't appreciate the danger until it was too late
Their house has appreciated significantly over the past decade
Gold tends to appreciate during economic uncertainty

definitions: arrest or take into custody especially by legal authority for suspected criminal activity
understand or perceive something mentally through intellectual grasp or recognition
anticipate something with anxiety or fear about what might happen
examples: Police apprehended the suspect after a brief chase downtown
The fugitive was finally apprehended at the border crossing
It took time to apprehend the full complexity of the theory
Young children cannot apprehend abstract concepts easily
She apprehended disaster when she saw the storm approaching
He apprehended danger in every shadow

definitions: work as an apprentice learning a trade or craft from a skilled employer
examples: She apprenticed with a master carpenter for three years
Young artists often apprentice in established studios to learn

definitions: come near or nearer to someone or something in distance or time
speak to someone for the first time about something especially to make a request
start dealing with a task or problem in a particular way or method
examples: The train slowly approached the station platform
Winter is approaching quickly this year
She nervously approached her boss about a raise
Several investors approached us with interesting offers
We need to approach this problem from a different angle
Each artist approaches the subject in their unique way

definitions: take something for one's own use typically without the owner's permission
allocate money or resources officially for a particular purpose or use
examples: He inappropriately appropriated company funds for personal use
The artist appropriated images from popular culture
Congress appropriated billions for disaster relief efforts
The committee appropriated funds for the new project

definitions: have or express a favorable opinion about someone or something
officially accept or agree to something formally such as a plan or request
examples: Her parents don't approve of her career choice
Most voters approve of the president's performance
The committee approved the budget after lengthy discussions
The FDA approved the new medication for public use

definitions: come close to something in quality quantity or degree but not exactly
estimate or calculate something roughly without exact precision
examples: The reproduction approximates the original painting remarkably well
This synthetic flavor approximates real vanilla
Scientists approximate the age of fossils using carbon dating
Can you approximate how many people attended?

definitions: act as a neutral third party to settle a dispute between opposing parties officially
examples: The judge will arbitrate between the two companies
She was chosen to arbitrate the labor dispute fairly

definitions: move in a curved trajectory through air or space like part of a circle
examples: The ball arced gracefully over the goalkeeper's outstretched hands
Lightning arced across the dark storm clouds

definitions: form or cause to form a curved shape like an arch especially by bending
move in a high curved trajectory through the air
examples: The cat arched its back when it felt threatened
She arched her eyebrows in surprise at the news
The dolphin arched through the air before diving back
The bridge arches elegantly over the river

definitions: place or store documents or records in an archive for long-term preservation and reference
examples: The library archives all historical newspapers on microfilm
Companies must archive financial records for seven years

definitions: exchange or express diverging or opposite views typically in a heated or angry way
give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea or theory systematically
examples: The siblings argue about everything from politics to sports
They argued for hours without reaching any agreement
The lawyer argued convincingly that her client was innocent
Scientists argue this theory explains the unusual results

definitions: get up from lying sitting or kneeling position to stand or become upright
come into being or to attention as a situation or problem requiring action
occur as a result or consequence of a particular situation or action
examples: She arose early every morning to practice yoga
The audience arose when the judge entered the courtroom
Several complications arose during the construction project
A new opportunity has arisen that we should consider
These problems arise from poor planning and communication
Misunderstandings often arise when people don't listen carefully

definitions: supply or provide someone with weapons or military equipment for fighting
prepare oneself with necessary tools or information for a particular situation
examples: The government decided to arm the rebel forces secretly
Countries continue to arm themselves with nuclear weapons
She armed herself with facts before the important debate
Arm yourself with patience for this lengthy process

definitions: cover or protect with armor or protective material against attack or damage
examples: Medieval knights would armor themselves before going into battle
The military armored their vehicles against roadside bombs

definitions: wake someone from sleep or cause to become active from an inactive state
evoke or awaken a feeling emotion or response in someone
stimulate someone sexually causing physical or psychological sexual excitement
examples: The loud thunder aroused everyone in the house
The smell of coffee aroused him from deep sleep
Her speech aroused strong emotions in the audience
The proposal aroused considerable interest among investors
The romantic scene was meant to arouse the viewers
Certain scents can arouse desire

definitions: put things in a neat attractive or ordered position according to a particular sequence
organize or make plans for an event or activity to take place
adapt a musical composition for performance with different instruments or voices
examples: She carefully arranged the flowers in the crystal vase
Please arrange these files in alphabetical order
I'll arrange a meeting for next Tuesday afternoon
They arranged a surprise party for her birthday
The composer arranged the symphony for a smaller orchestra
He arranged popular songs for jazz quartet

definitions: display or arrange things in a particular or impressive way
dress someone in elaborate or impressive clothes
examples: The store arrayed its finest jewelry in the window display
Products were arrayed on shelves according to price
The bride was arrayed in silk and pearls
Warriors arrayed themselves in ceremonial armor

definitions: seize someone by legal authority and take them into custody for a crime
stop or check the progress or movement of something
examples: Police arrested three suspects in connection with the robbery
The detective arrested him on charges of fraud
The new treatment can arrest the disease's progression
Quick action arrested the spread of the fire

definitions: reach a destination or particular place at the end of a journey
happen or come into being as an awaited event or moment
examples: The train arrives at platform three every hour
We arrived in Paris late yesterday evening
Spring has finally arrived after the long winter
The moment of truth has arrived at last

definitions: express thoughts ideas or feelings fluently and coherently in words
pronounce words clearly and distinctly so they can be understood
connect or form with joints allowing movement between rigid parts
examples: She articulated her concerns about the project clearly
He struggles to articulate complex ideas simply
The teacher asked students to articulate each syllable carefully
Actors must articulate well on stage
The robot's arm articulates at three different points
These bones articulate with each other at the joint
